source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.5 Referring to kin/friends that have no relationship to the speaker
notes: In Sakha there exists a special derivational suffix –LI: which is used to refer to people who are relatives or friends, but who do not have a relationship to the speaker. This suffix is homonymous to one of the adverbializing suffixes, e.g. нучча-лы: [Russian–ADVR] ‘in Russian’, as well as to the numeral distributive suffix, e.g. икки-ли: [two–DIST] ‘two each’. It occurs with nouns denoting siblings, e.g. быраат:тыы–лар [younger.brother–DER–PL] ‘brothers’, балыс-тыы–лар [younger.sister–DER–PL] ‘sisters’, эдьиий–дии=балыс–тыы–лар [older.sister–DER=younger.sister–DER–PL] ‘sisters’ (this emphasizes the fact that one is older, one younger), with ‘neighbour’, ‘family’, and ‘spouse’, e.g. ыал–лыы–лар [ neighbour–DER–PL] ‘neighbours’, аймах-тыы–лар [family–DER–PL] ‘relatives’, кэргэн–нии–лэр [spouse–DER–PL] ‘spouses’, with terms denoting friends, e.g. атас–тыы–lar [chum–DER–PL] ‘chums’, дьүөгэ–лии–лэр [girlfriend–DER–PL] ‘girlfriends’, and with саас ‘spring/age’, e.g. саас–тыы:–лар [spring–DER–PL] ‘people of the same age’. Thus, example (107a) means that Fedya is playing with his own two younger brothers, while (107b) means that he is playing with two boys who are brothers, but not his.
sah: Федя икки быраатын кытта оонҥуу сыльиар.
en: Fedya is playing with his two younger brothers. [F. two younger.brother–ACC.3SG join–IPF.CVB play–IPF.CVB IPFV–PRSPT]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.5 Referring to kin/friends that have no relationship to the speaker
notes: In Sakha there exists a special derivational suffix –LI: which is used to refer to people who are relatives or friends, but who do not have a relationship to the speaker. This suffix is homonymous to one of the adverbializing suffixes, e.g. нучча-лы: [Russian–ADVR] ‘in Russian’, as well as to the numeral distributive suffix, e.g. икки-ли: [two–DIST] ‘two each’. It occurs with nouns denoting siblings, e.g. быраат:тыы–лар [younger.brother–DER–PL] ‘brothers’, балыс-тыы–лар [younger.sister–DER–PL] ‘sisters’, эдьиий–дии=балыс–тыы–лар [older.sister–DER=younger.sister–DER–PL] ‘sisters’ (this emphasizes the fact that one is older, one younger), with ‘neighbour’, ‘family’, and ‘spouse’, e.g. ыал–лыы–лар [ neighbour–DER–PL] ‘neighbours’, аймах-тыы–лар [family–DER–PL] ‘relatives’, кэргэн–нии–лэр [spouse–DER–PL] ‘spouses’, with terms denoting friends, e.g. атас–тыы–lar [chum–DER–PL] ‘chums’, дьүөгэ–лии–лэр [girlfriend–DER–PL] ‘girlfriends’, and with саас ‘spring/age’, e.g. саас–тыы:–лар [spring–DER–PL] ‘people of the same age’. Thus, example (107a) means that Fedya is playing with his own two younger brothers, while (107b) means that he is playing with two boys who are brothers, but not his.
sah: Федя икки бырааттыылары кытта оонҥуу сыльиар.
en: Fedya is playing with two brothers. [F. two younger.brother–DER–PL–ACC join–IPF.CVB play–IPF.CVB IPFV–PRSPT]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
chapter: 3.4 Contact influence in the domain of possessive marking in Sakha
topic: 3.4.5 Referring to kin/friends that have no relationship to the speaker
notes: Similarly, in one of the narratives I recorded, the speaker is referring to other people who are related, and she excludes herself from this relationship.
sah: Ити Испиирэп кырдьаҕас Испииреп кэргэнэ аймахтыылар быһыылаах этэ онно кэлэн ааһар этэ.
en: Old Spirov’s wife was her (the grandmother’s) relatives it seems, she (the grandmother) came there. [this I. old I. spouse–POSS.3SG family–DER–PL appearance–PROP AUX–PST.3SG that.OBL–LOC come–PF.CVB pass–PRSPT AUX–PST.3SG]

source: Pakendorf B. Contact in the prehistory of the Sakha (Yakuts): Linguistic and genetic perspectives, 2007.
